questions.question: How is wealth defined?

choices.answer: How much money you have in your Checking and Saving accounts
Debts - Assets
All assets, including money in the bank + retirement
Assets - Debts

questions.question: Which of the following is FALSE about saving and investing?

choices.answer: Saving doesn't outpace inflation; investing usually does
Both saving and investing generally have low returns
Saving is for short-term; investing is for the longer-term
Saving has more risk; investing has less risk

questions.question: Which is NOT a typical goal for a savings account?

choices.answer: To create an emergency fund
To pay for higher education
To save for a new car
To buy groceries for this week

questions.question: What is a general rule of thumb on how much you should save?

choices.answer: 5% of your income
10% of your income
20% of your income
30% of your income

questions.question: What is a 529 account?

choices.answer: A type of retirement account for teens & younger adults
A special type of saving account for minors
A tax exempt fund that lets your savings grow for school
A special type of saving account for college students only

questions.question: About how much should you save in an emergency fund?

choices.answer: 1-3 months of living expenses
3-6 months of living expenses
6-9 months of living expenses
9-12 months of living expenses

questions.question: What is a good strategy to help you save?

choices.answer: 1st, spend money on all expenses; put the rest into saving
Tap into your savings regularly to purchase small items
Pay yourself first - set aside money for savings each month
Keep your spending and saving money together in 1 account

questions.question: Which of the following is FALSE about opening up a Roth IRA?

choices.answer: A person of any age with earned income can open one
It can help teens start saving for retirement early
Compounding occurs at a slower rate in a Roth IRA
You need to put at least $1,000 in it every year

questions.question: Which is TRUE about online saving accounts?

choices.answer: Usually have higher interest rates than non-online accounts
Usually have lower costs compared to brick-and-mortar banks
Online accounts are not FDIC insured
You can withdraw money an unlimited # of times

questions.question: What are some reasons for why so many Americans live paycheck-to-paycheck?

choices.answer: Many people are paying themselves first and then spending
Many people only buy what they NEED, not what they WANT
Many people impulse shop
Many people spend within their budget

questions.question: What is a benefit of opening up a Health Savings Account (HSA)?

choices.answer: The funds expire only every 5 years
You earn interest, but it's taxed
You can use the funds for retirement once you're 75
You can use pre-tax $ to pay for out-of-pocket costs

questions.question: How does the 50-20-30 rule distribute your income?

choices.answer: 50% expenses, 20% flexible spending, 30% saving
50% expenses, 20% saving, 30% flexible spending
50% flexible spending, 20% saving, 30% expenses
50% saving, 20% flexible spending, 30% expenses

questions.question: How is compound interest different than simple interest?

choices.answer: It is simple interest - interest earned on that interest
It is double the simple interest earned on an investment
It is simple interest + interest earned on that interest
It's not different; they are one and the same

questions.question: How does inflation impact the money in your savings account?

choices.answer: Inflation decreases only the $ you earn in interest
Inflation increases the value of the money in your account
The purchasing power of your money decreases over time
Inflation has no impact on $ in your savings account.

questions.question: Assuming a rate of growth of 8%, in how many years will your $ double?

choices.answer: 3 years
6 years
9 years
12 years

questions.question: At what rate does your $ need to grow at to double in 18 years?
Saving accounts differ from checking accounts in that...

choices.answer: Money in a saving account can be used to fund a bank's loans
Saving accounts let you withdraw $ an unlimited # of times
Saving accounts come with more fees than checking accounts
Checking accounts offer higher interest rates

questions.question: What might you need to open a savings account?

choices.answer: Identification
Minimum opening deposit
Your previous year's tax returns (or your parents')
The routing number to a checking account

questions.question: True or False: You need a checking account to open a savings account.

choices.answer: True
False

questions.question: Which is TRUE about Certificates of Deposit (CDs)?

choices.answer: You agree to keep $ in a CD for an undetermined time period
You pay the bank some interest to keep $ in the CD
The bank can loan out the $ in your CD
The bank pays you interest in return
